segment.source: User Account Control Only elevate executables that are signed and validated (Windows 10)
segment.target: User Account Control Only elevate executables that are signed and validated (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Only elevate executables that are signed and validated security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Only elevate executables that are signed and validated security policy setting.

segment.source: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated
segment.target: User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This policy setting enforces public key infrastructure (PKI) signature checks on any interactive application that requests elevation of privilege.
segment.target: This policy setting enforces public key infrastructure (PKI) signature checks on any interactive application that requests elevation of privilege.

segment.source: You can control the apps that are allowed to run through the population of certificates in the local computer's Trusted Publishers store.
segment.target: You can control the apps that are allowed to run through the population of certificates in the local computer's Trusted Publishers store.

segment.source: A trusted publisher is a certificate issuer that the computer’s user has chosen to trust and that has certificate details that have been added to the store of trusted publishers.
segment.target: A trusted publisher is a certificate issuer that the computer’s user has chosen to trust and that has certificate details that have been added to the store of trusted publishers.

segment.source: Windows maintains certificates in certificate stores.
segment.target: Windows maintains certificates in certificate stores.

segment.source: These stores can be represented by containers in the file system or the registry, or they can be implemented as physical stores such as smart cards.
segment.target: These stores can be represented by containers in the file system or the registry, or they can be implemented as physical stores such as smart cards.

segment.source: Certificate stores are associated with the computer object or they are owned by a distinct user who has a security context and profile on that computer.
segment.target: Certificate stores are associated with the computer object or they are owned by a distinct user who has a security context and profile on that computer.

segment.source: In addition, services can have certificate stores.
segment.target: In addition, services can have certificate stores.

segment.source: A certificate store will often contain numerous certificates, possibly issued from a number of different certification authorities (CAs).
segment.target: A certificate store will often contain numerous certificates, possibly issued from a number of different certification authorities (CAs).

segment.source: When certificate path discovery is initiated, Windows attempts to locate the issuing CA for the certificates, and it builds a certificate path to the trusted root certificate.
segment.target: When certificate path discovery is initiated, Windows attempts to locate the issuing CA for the certificates, and it builds a certificate path to the trusted root certificate.

segment.source: Intermediate certificates are included as part of the application protocol or are picked up from Group Policy or through URLs that are specified in the Authority Information Access (AIA) extension.
segment.target: Intermediate certificates are included as part of the application protocol or are picked up from Group Policy or through URLs that are specified in the Authority Information Access (AIA) extension.

segment.source: When the path is built, each certificate in the path is verified for validity with respect to various parameters, such as name, time, signature, revocation status, and other constraints.
segment.target: When the path is built, each certificate in the path is verified for validity with respect to various parameters, such as name, time, signature, revocation status, and other constraints.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Enforces the PKI certificate chain validation of a given executable file before it is permitted to run.
segment.target: Enforces the PKI certificate chain validation of a given executable file before it is permitted to run.

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Does not enforce PKI certificate chain validation before a given executable file is permitted to run.
segment.target: Does not enforce PKI certificate chain validation before a given executable file is permitted to run.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: Best practices are dependent on your security and performance goals.
segment.target: Best practices are dependent on your security and performance goals.

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a computer restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a computer restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: All auditing capabilities are integrated in Group Policy.
segment.target: All auditing capabilities are integrated in Group Policy.

segment.source: You can configure, deploy, and manage these settings in the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) or Local Security Policy snap-in for a domain, site, or organizational unit (OU).
segment.target: You can configure, deploy, and manage these settings in the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) or Local Security Policy snap-in for a domain, site, or organizational unit (OU).

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Intellectual property, personally identifiable information, and other confidential data are normally manipulated by applications on the computer, and elevated credentials are required to access the information.
segment.target: Intellectual property, personally identifiable information, and other confidential data are normally manipulated by applications on the computer, and elevated credentials are required to access the information.

segment.source: Users and administrators inherently trust applications that are used with these information sources, and they provide their credentials.
segment.target: Users and administrators inherently trust applications that are used with these information sources, and they provide their credentials.

segment.source: If one of these applications is replaced by a rogue application that appears identical to the trusted application, the confidential data could be compromised and the user's administrative credentials would also be compromised.
segment.target: If one of these applications is replaced by a rogue application that appears identical to the trusted application, the confidential data could be compromised and the user's administrative credentials would also be compromised.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Enable the User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated.
segment.target: Enable the User Account Control: Only elevate executables that are signed and validated.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: Enabling this setting requires that you have a PKI infrastructure and that your enterprise administrators have populated the Trusted Publishers store with the certificates for the allowed applications.
segment.target: Enabling this setting requires that you have a PKI infrastructure and that your enterprise administrators have populated the Trusted Publishers store with the certificates for the allowed applications.

segment.source: Some older applications are not signed, and they cannot be used in an environment that is hardened with this setting.
segment.target: Some older applications are not signed, and they cannot be used in an environment that is hardened with this setting.

segment.source: You should carefully test your applications in a preproduction environment before implementing this setting.
segment.target: You should carefully test your applications in a preproduction environment before implementing this setting.

segment.source: Control over the applications that are installed on the desktops and the hardware that joins your domain should provide similar protection from the vulnerability that is addressed by this setting.
segment.target: Control over the applications that are installed on the desktops and the hardware that joins your domain should provide similar protection from the vulnerability that is addressed by this setting.

segment.source: Additionally, the level of protection that is provided by this setting is not an assurance that all rogue applications will be found.
segment.target: Additionally, the level of protection that is provided by this setting is not an assurance that all rogue applications will be found.
